block.p: House Votes to Close Loophole in Gun Law The House voted to close a loophole in gun control laws that allowed the Virginia Tech gunman to buy firearms even though he had been committed to a mental hospital.
The Senate is likely to follow suit, which would be the first time since 1996 that Congress has given full approval to a measure strengthening gun control.
PAGE A20

Ex-Aides to Bush Subpoenaed Senate and House committees issued subpoenas to Harriet E. Miers, the former White House counsel, and Sara M. Taylor, the former political director, raising pressure on the White House to cooperate with their inquiry into the dismissal of nine federal prosecutors.
PAGE A22

Bank Plans Downtown Tower After months of sharp bargaining and threats to relocate, JPMorgan Chase is expected to announce that it has struck a deal with the governor and the Port Authority to build a skyscraper near ground zero and move its investment banking headquarters from Midtown.
PAGE B1

Hmong Split After Arrest A Hmong leader in the United States is accused of conspiring to oust the Laotian government. His arrest revealed a split between Hmong who fled Laos and those who grew up in this country.
PAGE A20

A Froot Loops Remake Kellogg says it will phase out ads aimed at children under 12 unless the products meet nutrition guidelines, a move likely to require reformulating some popular products like Froot Loops and Pop-Tarts.
BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1

A Fierce Figure, 70 Million Years Old An artist's impression of a birdlike dinosaur that lived 70 million years ago was released in Beijing. Scientists announced that they had uncovered its fossil skeleton in the Inner Mongolia region of northern China.
PAGE A18

Baron Guy de Rothschild Dies The heir to the House of Rothschild banking family, who rebuilt its Paris bank after it was seized by France during World War II, was 98. In addition to his financial acumen, the baron was celebrated for the family wine, Château Lafite-Rothschild, and for his thoroughbred racehorses.
PAGE A29

Only Age in Common Roger Clemens has made headlines with his midseason return to the Yankees, but David Wells, another 44-year-old pitcher, has stayed under the radar while pitching all season for the San Diego Padres.
SPORTSTHURSDAY, PAGE D1
Seeking a Chiseled Look Some adolescent boys, embarrassed by their enlarged breasts, are having them surgically reduced, even though waiting for their bodies to mature might be wiser.
